RADIO SURVEY
A survey to determine the size of the radio listening public not participaÂ¬
ting in discussion groups as such was carried on during the seventh broadcast in the
series. The sample consisted of one per cent of the 26,000 names listed in the San
Bernardino city telephone directory, a corps of volunteers was recruited and trained
to conduct the survey.
During the broadcast a total of 260 calls were made to residences within
the city limits j 183 were completed, 109 homes were watching one of seven TV chan -
nels receivable in the area, 22 were listeneding to radio. Of the 22 radio listening
other
homes, 10 were listening to the "Ways of Mankind" program, 19/persons answering
had listened to previous "Ways of Mankind" broadcasts and could identify individual
programs. 23 more persons expressed some familiarity with the series but were
rather hazy when asked for specifics. In no case was anyone identified with a
discussion group contacted.
Running these data through one radio survey formula, we will note that the
"Ways of Mankind" broadcast captured roughly 9.2$ of the total radio and television
sets in use. On the other hand if we "hooperize" the radio sets-in-use figure
alone, we discover that the program had built itself a 44.4$ share of the radio
listening audience. This, in the face of the program competition of three separate
(and with good reception) national network stations (two in Los Angeles, one local)
plus the looal fare of eight independent stations,
A number of conclusions can be supported directly by these figures. First of
all that there is an audience for well-produced educational radio, whether or not
the programs are shored up with organized receptor groups. What portion of this
audience was attracted by the extensive promotion given the "Ways of Mankind" series,
what portion grew out of previous listening habits, or dial twisting encounter with
a given broadcast is impossible to assess.
